title: Common Cough
oneMinuteSummary: A cough is a reflex that helps clear your throat and airways.
eli5Summary: Your body is like a hallway with a door. A cough is the door slamming to push out dust.
whatsHappening: Nerves in your throat or airways sense irritation.
Your body pushes air out quickly to clear the irritation.
Coughs can come with mucus or be dry.

analogy.title: The hallway sweep
analogy.story: Imagine sweeping a hallway. A cough is a quick sweep to push out something that does not belong.

peopleOftenNotice: Coughing more at night or after talking
A dry or wet sound when coughing
generalSelfCare: Many people focus on warm drinks and gentle rest for comfort.
Keeping the air moist can feel soothing.
Some people keep a short note of triggers to discuss with a clinician.

visuals.title: Airway irritation
visuals.alt: Simple airway diagram with a tickle icon in the throat

title: Sore Throat (General)
oneMinuteSummary: A sore throat means the tissues in your throat feel irritated or tender.
eli5Summary: Your throat is like a soft tunnel. When it is irritated, it can feel scratchy.
whatsHappening: Throat tissue can swell when it is irritated.
The surface can become dry or sensitive.
Swallowing can feel uncomfortable because the tissue is tender.

analogy.title: Soft tunnel
analogy.story: Think of your throat as a soft tunnel. If the tunnel lining gets rubbed, it can feel sore.

generalSelfCare: Some people sip warm liquids for comfort.
Resting the voice can feel helpful.
Keeping indoor air less dry can feel soothing.

visuals.title: Throat irritation
visuals.alt: Simple diagram of a throat with gentle irritation marks

title: Runny Nose / Congestion
oneMinuteSummary: A runny or stuffy nose happens when the nose lining makes extra fluid or swells.
eli5Summary: Your nose is like a filter. When it is bothered, it makes extra water to wash things out.
whatsHappening: The nose lining can swell, making airflow feel tight.
Extra mucus helps trap dust or germs.
Swelling and mucus together cause stuffiness.

analogy.title: The busy filter
analogy.story: Picture a filter that flushes itself with water. A runny nose is that cleaning rinse.

peopleOftenNotice: Needing to blow the nose often
generalSelfCare: Many people find gentle steam helpful for comfort.
Staying hydrated can support overall comfort.
Some people use a soft tissue to reduce irritation.

visuals.title: Nasal lining swelling
visuals.alt: Simple nose diagram showing a swollen lining and airflow

title: Mild Headache
oneMinuteSummary: A mild headache is a common head pain that can feel dull or tight.
eli5Summary: Your head is like a drum. If the drum is a bit tense, it can ache.
whatsHappening: Pain signals can come from muscles, nerves, or blood vessels around the head.
Tension in the neck or scalp can add pressure.
The brain senses these signals as pain.

analogy.title: The tense drum
analogy.story: A drum sounds different when it is too tight. A mild headache can feel like that tightness.

peopleOftenNotice: A dull ache on both sides of the head
generalSelfCare: Some people rest in a quiet, dim space for comfort.
Gentle neck stretching can feel soothing for some people.
Keeping regular meals and water can help overall comfort.

visuals.title: Head tension zones
visuals.alt: Simple head outline with tension areas highlighted

title: Nausea (General)
oneMinuteSummary: Nausea is the uneasy feeling that you might vomit.
eli5Summary: Your stomach is like a washing machine. Nausea feels like it is swirling the wrong way.
whatsHappening: Signals from the stomach, inner ear, or brain can trigger nausea.
The stomach may slow down its normal movement.
The body prepares to protect itself by feeling queasy.

analogy.title: The spinning washer
analogy.story: Imagine a washer that spins too fast. Your body notices and feels unsettled.

generalSelfCare: Some people prefer small sips of clear liquids.
Resting upright can feel more comfortable for some people.
Gentle, plain foods can feel easier for some people.

visuals.title: Stomach signals
visuals.alt: Simple diagram of stomach with signal lines to the brain

extraDetail.generalSelfCare: Many people keep a small comfort kit nearby, like water and light snacks, so they can move slowly when the feeling passes.

title: Hangover
oneMinuteSummary: A hangover is a group of symptoms that can happen after drinking alcohol.
eli5Summary: Your body had to clean up a mess, and now it feels tired and sore.
whatsHappening: Alcohol can irritate the stomach and affect sleep.
It can cause the body to lose water.
The body works to break down alcohol, which can leave you feeling worn out.

analogy.title: Cleanup crew
analogy.story: Think of your body as a cleanup crew after a big party. The next day, the crew feels tired.

generalSelfCare: Many people focus on rest and hydration for comfort.
Light, bland foods can feel easier for some people.
Some people prefer quiet, low-light spaces while they recover.

visuals.title: Body cleanup
visuals.alt: Simple icon of a broom inside a body outline

title: Heartburn (General)
oneMinuteSummary: Heartburn is a burning feeling in the chest when stomach acid moves upward.
eli5Summary: Your stomach is like a bottle with a lid. If the lid loosens, some liquid can splash up.
whatsHappening: A valve between the stomach and food tube can relax.
Acid can move upward and irritate the food tube.
That irritation feels like a warm or burning sensation.

analogy.title: The loose bottle cap
analogy.story: Picture a bottle with a loose cap. A small splash can move up and feel uncomfortable.

peopleOftenNotice: Burning in the chest after eating
generalSelfCare: Some people find smaller meals feel gentler.
Sitting upright after meals can feel more comfortable.
Loose clothing around the waist can reduce pressure.

visuals.title: Acid moving upward
visuals.alt: Simple diagram of stomach and food tube with arrows upward

extraDetail.analogy: If the cap stays loose often, the splash can happen more than once, which helps explain why some people notice repeated episodes.

title: Diarrhea (General)
oneMinuteSummary: Diarrhea means loose or watery stools because the gut moves too fast.
eli5Summary: Your intestines are like a long hallway. When things move too fast, water does not get absorbed.
whatsHappening: The intestines usually absorb water from food.
When movement is faster, less water is absorbed.
Stool becomes loose or watery.

analogy.title: The fast conveyor belt
analogy.story: Imagine a conveyor belt moving too quickly. Items slide by before they can be sorted.

generalSelfCare: Many people focus on steady fluids to stay comfortable.
Plain foods can feel easier on the stomach.
Some people rest to let the body settle.

visuals.title: Fast-moving gut
visuals.alt: Simple diagram of intestines with fast arrows

title: Constipation (General)
oneMinuteSummary: Constipation means bowel movements are less frequent or harder to pass.
eli5Summary: Your intestines are like a slow-moving train. When it slows too much, things back up.
whatsHappening: The large intestine absorbs water from stool.
When stool stays longer, it becomes drier.
Dry stool can feel harder to pass.

analogy.title: The slow train
analogy.story: If a train slows on the track, more passengers pile up. Constipation is like that slowdown.

generalSelfCare: Many people focus on fiber-rich foods and steady fluids for comfort.
Gentle movement can support normal gut rhythm for some people.
Some people keep a regular routine for bathroom time.

visuals.title: Slow-moving stool
visuals.alt: Simple intestines diagram with slow arrows

title: Muscle Soreness After Exercise
oneMinuteSummary: Muscle soreness after exercise is a normal response to new or hard movement.
eli5Summary: Your muscles are like rubber bands. If they stretch in new ways, they feel sore later.
whatsHappening: Small muscle fibers can get tiny stress during exercise.
The body repairs those fibers, which can feel sore.
This repair can make muscles stronger over time.

analogy.title: The stretched rubber band
analogy.story: Stretching a rubber band in new ways can make it feel tight. Muscles can feel that way too.

peopleOftenNotice: Soreness in the muscles used most
generalSelfCare: Some people use gentle movement and rest to stay comfortable.
Light stretching can feel calming for some people.
Keeping a steady routine can help the body adapt.

visuals.title: Muscle fiber repair
visuals.alt: Simple muscle fibers with small repair lines

resources.label: American Council on Exercise: Muscle soreness

title: Trouble Sleeping (Short-Term)
oneMinuteSummary: Short-term sleep trouble means it is hard to fall asleep or stay asleep for a few nights.
eli5Summary: Your brain has a night switch. Sometimes the switch gets stuck between on and off.
whatsHappening: Stress or schedule changes can shift your sleep rhythm.
The brain stays alert when it expects activity.
Light, noise, or screens can make it harder to feel sleepy.

analogy.title: The stuck night switch
analogy.story: Think of a light switch that flickers. It takes time for it to settle into the off position.

generalSelfCare: Many people keep a consistent sleep routine for comfort.
A calm, dark room can feel helpful.
Some people wind down with quiet activities before bed.

visuals.title: Sleep rhythm
visuals.alt: Simple moon and clock diagram

title: Stress/Anxiety Feelings (General Education)
oneMinuteSummary: Stress or anxiety feelings happen when the body senses pressure or worry.
eli5Summary: Your body has an alarm system. Sometimes it rings even when you are safe.
whatsHappening: The brain sends signals that speed up the heart and breathing.
Muscles can tighten to get ready for action.
The mind may focus on worries to stay prepared.

analogy.title: The sensitive alarm
analogy.story: A smoke alarm can beep from steam. Stress can be a sensitive alarm too.

generalSelfCare: Some people find slow breathing calming.
Gentle movement or stretching can feel grounding.
Jotting down worries can help organize thoughts.

visuals.title: Body alarm response
visuals.alt: Simple body outline with lightning bolt symbols

extraDetail.generalSelfCare: Some people use short breaks during the day to reset, such as a quick walk or a few quiet minutes.

title: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure) — Diagnosed
oneMinuteSummary: High blood pressure means your blood is pushing too hard on your blood vessel walls over time.
eli5Summary: Imagine a hose. If the water pushes too hard all day, the hose can wear out faster.
whatsHappening: Your heart pumps blood through tubes called blood vessels.
If the pressure stays high, the vessel walls get stressed over time.
Over years, that stress can make the heart and blood vessels work harder.

analogy.title: The garden hose analogy
analogy.story: Blood vessels are like a hose. If the water pressure is too high for too long, the hose can get damaged or stiff. Lower, steady pressure is kinder to the hose.

peopleOftenNotice: Many people feel nothing at first
Some people notice headaches or feeling off, but this varies
generalSelfCare: Some people focus on routines that support heart health, like regular sleep and movement.
Reducing stress can help some people feel better overall.
Many people find it helpful to track questions and bring them to appointments.
questionsForClinician: What is my target blood pressure range?
How often should I check it, and how should I record it?
What lifestyle changes matter most for me?
How will we monitor this over time?

visuals.title: Blood pressure as force on vessel walls
visuals.alt: Simple diagram showing blood flowing through a tube with pressure arrows on the walls

resources.label: American Heart Association: High Blood Pressure

title: Asthma — Diagnosed
oneMinuteSummary: Asthma means the airways can get narrow and sensitive, which can make breathing feel tight.
eli5Summary: Your breathing tubes are like soft straws. Asthma makes the straws squeeze smaller sometimes.
whatsHappening: Airways can swell and make extra mucus.
Muscles around the airways can tighten.
Together, these changes make air move through a smaller space.

analogy.title: The pinched straw
analogy.story: If you pinch a straw, less air can pass through. Asthma can feel like that pinch.

generalSelfCare: Many people track patterns that seem to trigger symptoms.
Gentle breathing exercises can feel calming.
Planning activities with rest breaks can feel supportive.
questionsForClinician: How can I recognize my early warning signs?
What is my personal asthma action plan?
How often should my lung function be checked?

visuals.title: Airways narrowing
visuals.alt: Simple airway diagram comparing open and narrowed tubes

extraDetail.generalSelfCare: Some people keep notes on air quality or seasonal changes so they can discuss patterns at visits.

title: GERD — Diagnosed
oneMinuteSummary: GERD means stomach acid often moves back into the food tube, causing irritation.
eli5Summary: Your stomach is a bottle. GERD is when the bottle leaks upward more often.
whatsHappening: The valve between the stomach and food tube relaxes too often.
Acid rises and irritates the lining.
Repeated irritation can lead to ongoing discomfort.

analogy.title: The leaky bottle
analogy.story: If a bottle leaks, the liquid touches places it should not. That is how reflux can feel.

peopleOftenNotice: Symptoms that feel worse after meals
generalSelfCare: Some people find smaller meals more comfortable.
Sitting upright after eating can feel supportive.
Keeping a simple food and symptom log can be useful for appointments.
questionsForClinician: How can I track my symptoms effectively?
What changes help reduce reflux for me?
How will we monitor my esophagus over time?

visuals.title: Acid reflux path
visuals.alt: Simple diagram of acid moving upward

title: Migraine — Diagnosed
oneMinuteSummary: Migraine is a brain condition that can cause strong headaches and sensitivity to light or sound.
eli5Summary: Your brain is like a control center. During a migraine, the controls get overwhelmed.
whatsHappening: Brain signaling changes can make nerves more sensitive.
Blood vessels and nerves around the brain can react.
This can lead to head pain and sensory sensitivity.

analogy.title: The overloaded control room
analogy.story: Imagine a control room with too many alarms at once. Everything feels loud and bright.

generalSelfCare: Some people rest in a dark, quiet space.
Keeping a migraine diary can help identify patterns.
Gentle routines can support steady sleep.
questionsForClinician: What triggers should I track?
How can I describe my migraine pattern?
What is my long-term management plan?

visuals.title: Sensitive brain signals
visuals.alt: Simple brain diagram with signal lines

extraDetail.generalSelfCare: Some people plan quiet recovery time after a migraine and write down what seemed helpful to discuss later.

title: Type 2 Diabetes — Diagnosed (Education Only)
oneMinuteSummary: Type 2 diabetes means the body has trouble using insulin to move sugar from the blood into cells.
eli5Summary: Sugar is fuel. Insulin is the key. In type 2 diabetes, the key works poorly.
whatsHappening: Insulin helps move sugar into cells for energy.
In type 2 diabetes, cells resist insulin's signal.
Sugar stays in the blood longer than it should.

analogy.title: The sticky key
analogy.story: If a key sticks in a lock, the door does not open smoothly. Insulin can feel like a sticky key.

generalSelfCare: Some people focus on steady routines for meals and activity.
Tracking questions helps make clinic visits more focused.
Learning about glucose numbers can feel empowering.
questionsForClinician: What blood sugar targets are right for me?
How should I monitor my numbers?
What lifestyle changes make the biggest difference for me?

visuals.title: Sugar and insulin
visuals.alt: Simple cells and sugar icons with a key

title: Anemia — Diagnosed (Education Only)
oneMinuteSummary: Anemia means the blood has fewer red cells or less hemoglobin to carry oxygen.
eli5Summary: Red blood cells are like delivery trucks for oxygen. In anemia, there are fewer trucks.
whatsHappening: Red blood cells carry oxygen to the body.
With fewer cells or lower hemoglobin, oxygen delivery slows.
This can make the body feel tired or weak.

analogy.title: The delivery trucks
analogy.story: If a town has fewer delivery trucks, packages arrive slowly. Oxygen delivery can feel like that.

generalSelfCare: Some people track energy levels to share with their clinician.
Gentle pacing can help conserve energy.
Learning the cause of anemia helps guide discussions with care teams.
questionsForClinician: What type of anemia do I have?
What tests will help us find the cause?
How will we track my progress?

visuals.title: Oxygen delivery
visuals.alt: Simple red blood cells carrying oxygen icons

title: High Cholesterol — Diagnosed
oneMinuteSummary: High cholesterol means there is more fat-like material in the blood than usual.
eli5Summary: Cholesterol is like grease in plumbing. Too much can build up on the walls.
whatsHappening: Cholesterol travels in the blood to help build cells.
Extra cholesterol can stick to blood vessel walls.
Over time, that buildup can narrow the space for blood flow.

analogy.title: Grease in pipes
analogy.story: If grease builds up inside a pipe, less water can pass through. Cholesterol buildup can feel similar.

peopleOftenNotice: Some learn about it from routine tests
Others notice related health concerns over time
generalSelfCare: Some people focus on heart-healthy routines, like movement and balanced meals.
Tracking lab results can help guide questions for visits.
Keeping stress lower can support overall heart health.
questionsForClinician: What type of cholesterol numbers matter most for me?
How often should I check my levels?
What lifestyle changes are recommended for my situation?

visuals.title: Cholesterol buildup
visuals.alt: Simple blood vessel with buildup along the wall

title: Anxiety Disorder — Diagnosed (Education Only)
oneMinuteSummary: An anxiety disorder means worry or fear is frequent and hard to control.
eli5Summary: Your body alarm system rings too often, even when things are okay.
whatsHappening: The brain’s alarm system can stay activated.
Stress hormones can keep the body on alert.
This can affect sleep, focus, and energy.

analogy.title: The overactive alarm
analogy.story: A car alarm that goes off too easily can feel exhausting. Anxiety can feel like that alarm.

peopleOftenNotice: Worry that feels hard to stop
generalSelfCare: Some people use grounding techniques like slow breathing.
Keeping routines can feel stabilizing.
Writing down questions can make appointments easier.
questionsForClinician: What type of anxiety disorder do I have?
What treatment options are available?
How can I track progress over time?

visuals.title: Alarm system
visuals.alt: Simple brain and alarm icon

extraDetail.generalSelfCare: Some people find that gentle structure, like a daily plan, reduces the feeling of being overwhelmed.
